channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: ã€Go 1.24 arrivesã€‘åˆ°è¾¾1.24
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹542 â€” February 12, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ–ï¸ We're taking next week off, so the next issue will be on Wednesday, February 26. Feel free to hit reply and send in any submissions!
__
Peter Cooper, your editor.

Go Weekly

Go 1.24 Released â€” Finally, after many months of blog posts getting excited about Go 1.24â€™s new features, the real deal has arrived. Itâ€™s a reasonably big release too, including a lot ofÂ updates:

  • The go tool mechanism for tracking tool dependencies.
  • The use of Swiss Tables to speed up map operations.
  • Experimental testing/synctest package for testing concurrentÂ code.
  • The go:wasmexport directive to export functions to a WASMÂ host.
  • Support for generic type aliases, as well as weak pointers.
  • A new mechanism to achieve FIPS 140-3 compliance.
As always, the ultimate source of truth is the thorough releaseÂ notes but don't forget the interactive Go 1.24 tourÂ either.

Junyang Shao and the Go Team

ğŸ’¡ Jamie Tanna is also pretty excited about the new omitzero field tag for JSONÂ marshalling.

Reduce Your Apache Kafka Costs + Ops Burden With WarpStream â€” WarpStream reduces Kafka costs by 80+% by eliminating disks and interzone networking fees and features zero ops auto-scaling. It runs in your private cloud and data is stored in your object storage buckets, so raw data never leaves yourÂ environment.

WarpStream sponsor

Go Slice Gotchas â€” â€œJust like any other dynamically growable container structure, slices come with a few gotchas. I donâ€™t always remember all the rules I need to be aware of, so this is an attempt to list some of the most common mistakes Iâ€™ve made at leastÂ once.â€

Redowan Delowar

IN BRIEF:

  • Joe Tsai kicks off a proposal for encoding/json/v2, a new standard API for encoding/json.

  • ğŸ”’ Microsoft maintains its own Go build to bring FIPS compliance to Go's crypto libraries. Vanilla Go has been trying to obtain a FIPS validation directly and v1.24 adds a mechanism for this. However, MS is sticking with its approach and here's an explanation of why, as well as a look at support forÂ macOS.

  • ğŸ“» TinyGo's Ron Evans recently â–¶ï¸ gave a talk at FOSDEM's Go devroom demonstrating using Go with microcontrollers to communicate over 'a variety of frequencies of the electromagnetic spectrum.'

  • Originally a set of shell scripts, the latest version of the asdf version manager sees a complete rewrite to Go â€“ explained in full detail here.

We Replaced Our React Frontend with Go and WebAssembly â€” Even if you wouldnâ€™t want to do this, itâ€™s interesting to read about the experience of a team thatÂ has.

Alex Suraci (Dagger)

OpenTelemetry: A Guide to Observability with Go â€” A thorough introduction with plenty of codeÂ examples.

Luca Cavallin

Eliminating Shadow Access: The Hidden Dangers of SSH and APIÂ Keys â€” Static keys create hidden security risks. Learn how to replace them with dynamic, identity-based access. RegisterÂ now!

Teleport sponsor

ğŸ“„ Why Does io.Reader Have Such a Weird Signature? â€“ And thereâ€™s actually a goodÂ answer. Redowan Delowar

ğŸ§ Discussing Security, Devops and Testing in Go with Jakub Jarosz go podcast()

ğŸ“„ How I Developed a Markdown Blog with Go and HTMX Fluxsec

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

sturdyc: Caching Library with Advanced Concurrency Features â€” â€œA sturdy gopher shielding data sources from rapidly incoming requests.â€ Designed to avoid cache stampedes and overloading in high throughput systems by providing non-blocking reads and sharded writes for minimal lockÂ contention.

Victor Conner

go-taskflow: A Taskflow-Like DAG Task Execution Framework â€” A general-purpose task-parallel framework for Go, suitable for complex dependency management in concurrentÂ tasks.

NoneBack

EasyCache: A New, Simple In-Memory Caching Library
Hugo Carreira

go-nfs: An NFSv3 Server in Pure go â€” Still a work inÂ progress.
Will Scott

  • ğŸ¤– Go OpenAI 1.37 â€“ An OpenAI API wrapperÂ library. Now with support for the new o3-miniÂ model. There's also OpenAI's official Go libraryÂ now.

  • golangci-lint v1.64.2 â€“ Fast linter runner, now supporting Go 1.24.

  • GoReleaser 2.7 â€“ Build/release binaries for multipleÂ platforms.

  • Slack API in Go 0.16 â€“ Use the Slack chat system's API from Go, unsurprisingly.

  • pgRoll 0.9 â€“ Zero-downtime, reversible schema migrations forÂ Postgres.

  • ğŸ•’ Quartz 0.14 â€“ Zero-dependency job scheduling library.

  • pgxmock 4.5 â€“ Mock driver to test PostgresÂ interactions.

  • fq 0.14 â€“ Like jq for binaryÂ formats.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

âš¡Fast, Accurate, Reliable â€“ CarsXE eliminates manual corrections with real-time vehicle data. Get startedÂ now!

ğŸ¹ STRICH: Add blazing fast and reliable 1D/2D Barcode Scanning to your web apps. Free demo app and 30-day trialÂ available.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in dev

A quick roundup of some of other interesting stories in the broader landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • Beej, author of numerous popular guides to programming concepts, has released Beej's Guide to Git, a great zero-to-expert online resource for using the world's most popularÂ DVCS.

  • Learn Shader Programming with Rick and Morty is a fun way to learn some interesting GLSL techniques from the ground up.

  • DB Fiddle is a handy online database 'sandbox' for playing with various versions of MySQL, Postgres, and SQLite direct from the browser.

  • Go is pretty good with WebAssembly now, but I never thought I'd see a Ruby on Rails app running in the browser thanks toÂ WASM.

  • Microsoft has open sourced DocumentDB, a Postgres extension for bring a full fledged document-oriented NoSQL database into theÂ mix.

ã€‘

item.title: ã€How Swiss Tables make Go 1.24 fasterã€‘ç‘å£«æ¡Œå­å¦‚ä½•æ›´å¿«åœ°1.24
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹544 â€” March 5, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Faster Go Maps with Swiss Tables â€” One of Goâ€™s newest features is a revamped map implementation powered by a new hash table algorithm called Swiss Table that boosts map operations up to 60% faster in microbenchmarks, while reducing memory overhead. Hereâ€™s a look at how itÂ works.

Michael Pratt

Tips to Debug Hanging Go Programs â€” Next time your Go app becomes unresponsive, these tips can help you find the issue by forcing a stack trace or using Delve to attach to the process (or core dump) and revive theÂ program.

Michael Stapelberg

Keep Postgres Maintenance from Slowing Down Your Go App â€” Secure your spot to learn the proactive maintenance practices that uncover hidden database performance risks, like slow queries, checkpoint behavior, & connection issues, before theyÂ escalate.

pganalyze sponsor

The Cost of Go's panic and recover â€” When something goes unexpectedly and critically wrong in a Go program you might use panic to abort things quickly, but did you know you can use recover to manage what happens after a panic? This means you could use it as a sort of control flow mechanism, if you were in a particularly unorthodoxÂ mood..

Julien Cretel

ğŸ’¡ This post led to a rather extensive discussion on Hacker News.

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ GopherConUK returns to London this August and its call for papers has just opened if you'd like to speak. You can submit a talk up until MayÂ 17.

  • go-attention is an attempt to create a pure Go implementation of attention mechanisms and transformer layers, such as used in modernÂ LLMs.

Calling Rust from 'Cursed' Go â€” Cgo is Goâ€™s mechanism for calling external/foreign functions but its performance often causes consternation. Enter purego, a still-in-beta way to make such calls without Cgo.

Preston Thorpe

Nil Channels in Go â€” Nil channels seem to baffle many Gophers, so Vishnu went on a quest to figure out why in a particular case. This led him to the wisdom of a new Go proverb: â€œInit when you split; Nil when youÂ merge.â€

Vishnu Bharathi

The Magic of Small Engineering Teams â€” How PostHog uses small teams to ship fast and scale at the sameÂ time.

PostHog sponsor

ğŸ“„ Minesweeper with Raylib Go Bindings â€“ Alex reflects on the joys of basic game development in Go with Raylib and he shares his codeÂ too. Alex Pliutau

ğŸ“„ We Switched from Java to Go and Don't Regret It Miglinci, Steiner, and Enne (Glasskube)

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Gore 0.6: A Full Featured Go REPL Environment â€” You get all the niceties youâ€™d expect like line editing, history, multi-line input, the ability to import packages, and, in this latest build, gopls-powered code completionÂ too.

motemen

Go Clean Template â€” Inspired by Uncle Bobâ€™s â€˜Clean Codeâ€™ principles, this repo attempts to provide a â€˜clean architecture templateâ€™ for building Go-powered services that are well organized and wonâ€™t turn into a mess. You be theÂ judge.

Evrone

go-git 5.14: An Extensible Git Implementation in Pure Go â€” â€œManipulate git repositories at low level (plumbing) or high level (porcelain), through an idiomatic Go API.â€ Now requires GoÂ 1.23+.

go-git

sqldef 1.0: Idempotent Schema Management for Databases â€” A Go-powered CLI tool and WASM library for diffing SQL schemas (demo here). Supports MySQL, Postgres, SQLite and SQL Server. Built by one of Rubyâ€™s core teamÂ members,Â too.

Takashi Kokubun

  • â­ TinyGo 0.36.0 â€“ The much celebrated Go compiler 'for small places' gains Go 1.24 and LLVM 19 support, as well as support for several newÂ boards.

  • MongoDB Go Driver v2.1 â€“ Officially supported driver to work with MongoDB. Now supporting MongoDB's new bulk write API and BSON vectorÂ datatype.

  • gocron v2.16.0 â€“ Job scheduling package for running Go functions at specifiedÂ intervals.

  • Wait4X 3.0 â€“ CLI tool for waiting on various ports or services to reach a specifiedÂ state.

  • pgroll v0.10 â€“ Tool for zero-downtime, reversible schema PostgresÂ migrations.

  • Glow 2.1 â€“ Terminal-based Markdown rendering from the folks atÂ Charm.

  • Pion WebRTC 4.0.13 â€“ Pure Go implementation of the WebRTCÂ API.

  • Sarama v1.45.1 â€“ IBM's Go client library for ApacheÂ Kafka.

  • Hugo v0.145.0

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ“Œ Faster Deployment â€“ Integrate CarsXEâ€™s API in minutes and get real-time vehicle data with ease. Try it now!Â 

Blacksmith runs GitHub Actions 2x faster at half the cost with a one-line code change. Trusted by 250+ companies like Ashby andÂ Clerk.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in dev

A quick roundup of some of other interesting stories in the broader landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • ğŸ¤¯ Someone managed to implement 90s FPS game Doom entirely in the TypeScript type system.

  • And if you've never quite grokked how TypeScript ticks, Dr. Axel Rauschmayer has a succinct explanation of how it differs from JavaScript in a practical day-to-day tooling sense.

  • ğŸ¤– Microsoft and GitHub are getting into the 'AI developer agents' game and have showed off a look at GitHub Copilot 'agent mode' running in VSÂ Code.

  • Is it possible to think about game 'speedrunning' as essentially a form of vulnerability research?

ã€‘

Motemen

item.title: ã€sync/v2 and the 'v2'-ification of Go's standard libraryã€‘åŒæ­¥/v2å’ŒGOæ ‡å‡†åº“çš„â€œ V2'-aigiendationâ€
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹541 â€” February 5, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

How a Malicious Package Exploited Module Proxy Caching for Persistence â€” Researchers have uncovered a sophisticated supply chain attack exploiting both typosquatting and then Goâ€™s module proxying caching to remain undetected for years. Itâ€™s worth understanding the mechanism behind this in case you run into itÂ yourself.

Kirill Boychenko (Socket)

Proposal: math/rand/v2 Worked, Let's Do sync/v2! â€” Creating â€˜v2â€™ versions of standard packages is Goâ€™s compromise for modernization vs stability. With the evolution of math/rand a success, Ian thinks synchronization primitives are due an upgrade too. Much of the value here comes from a monthâ€™s worth of discussion, including peopleâ€™s discontent over the â€˜v2â€™ approach (outlined furtherÂ here).

Ian Lance Taylor

Upcoming Workshop on Building Backend Web Apps in Go â€” Join us for a two day workshop (either online or in person) and develop your Go know-how. We'll focus on using Go to build backend web apps, along with learning Go data structures, interfaces, how to write unit tests, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Go Programs Freezing When Launched by Steam â€” Ebitengineâ€™s lead developer reported an unusual bug to the Steam team â€“ Go programs (e.g. games) launched by the popular Steam game launcher were failing due to Steam interfering with Goâ€™s runtime in some way. This has since become a bug being discussed on the Go repo with some workarounds but no full resolutionÂ yet.

Hajime Hoshi

IN BRIEF:

  • While we wait for of Go 1.24's final release, Go 1.23.6 and Go 1.22.12 have been released including a security fix to crypto/elliptic as well as a couple of tiny bugÂ fixes.

  • Originally an elaborate set of shell scripts, the latest version of the asdf version manager sees a complete rewrite to Go. (I use this for managing my Ruby versions â€“ it's good.)

httptap: View HTTP/HTTPS Requests Made by Any Linux Program â€” It uses Linux-only network namespaces for now, but this is a Go-powered process-scoped HTTP tracer you can run without root privileges. It even decrypts TLS traffic by generating a CA on the fly. Handy for debugging or seeing if dependencies or apps are â€˜phoningÂ home,â€™Â perhaps..

Monastic Academy for the Preservation of Life on Earth

How to Release to Homebrew with GoReleaser, GitHub Actions and Semantic Release â€” The steps involved in automating the release of a Go project (maybe your new command line tool or TUI?) thatâ€™s available via Homebrew (as most commonly used onÂ macOS).

Billy Hadlow

Product Management Is Broken. Engineers Can Fix It â€” How redefining how PMs and engineers work together helped PostHog optimize everything they do for speed andÂ autonomy.

PostHog sponsor

ğŸ“„ Real-Time Batching in Go Viktor Nikolaiev

ğŸ“„ Recover Panics in All Goroutines You Start Emir Ribic

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Zog: 'Next Gen' Schema Validation for Go â€” Zod is a popular TypeScript-based runtime schema validation library and Zog is a take on the same idea in Go so you can define validations and run them against values and structs. GitHubÂ repo.

Tristan Mayo

etree 1.5: A Library to Parse and Generate XML Easily â€” A simple, straightforward approach to working with XML in Go, inspired by Pythonâ€™s ElementTree. XML documents are represented as trees for easily traversal and you can create, import, modify and save XML. Queries can be done with a XPath-likeÂ approach.

Brett Vickers

Feluda: A Tool to Analyze the Licences of Dependencies â€” Itâ€™s a Rust-powered project but which can be used to process the dependencies of Go, Rust or Node.js projects and return a report (or show a TUI interface) on potentially restrictive licenses thatÂ apply.

Kumar Anirudha

ğŸ”ŠÂ volume-go: A Cross-Platform Way to Control Sound Volume â€” Leaning on a different technique for each OS, it supports macOS, Linux, and Windows. If you want it wrapped up into a nice Go TUI, Volgo is forÂ you.

itchyny

  • ğŸ§‹ Bubble Tea 1.3 â€“ A popular way to build terminal apps. v1.3 now handles interrupts better and take your CTRL+Cs 'with grace andÂ poise.'

  • genqlient 0.8 â€“ Generate type-safe code to query a GraphQLÂ API.

  • Micro 5.0 â€“ Go distributed system abstractions /Â platform.

  • rain 2.2 â€“ BitTorrent client and library forÂ Go.

  • fzf 0.59 â€“ Popular command-line fuzzyÂ finder.

  • GoBGP 3.34 â€“ BGP implementation inÂ Go.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ’¡ Modern Infrastructure Demands a Modern Approach to Privileged Access - Read WhiteÂ Paper.

ğŸ˜ PostgreSQL user? Check out our sister newsletter, Postgres Weekly â€“ the next issue goes outÂ tomorrow.

ğŸ•¹ï¸Â  And for a little fun..

A Minesweeper Game Written in Go â€” A cute example of putting together a game in such a way that it not only runs on the desktop in the usual way, but can be taken to the Web too. The effects are cute, too â€“ this is a great use of the Ebitengine game engine. The GitHub repo is certainly worth a look if you're trying to reach similarÂ ends.

imprity

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>

tristan mayo

Brett Vickers

- è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç”±ç”Ÿé”ˆçš„é¡¹ç›®ï¼Œä½†å¯ç”¨äºå¤„ç†GOï¼ŒRustæˆ–Node.jsé¡¹ç›®çš„ä¾èµ–é¡¹ï¼Œå¹¶è¿”å›æœ‰å…³é€‚ç”¨çš„æ½œåœ¨é™åˆ¶æ€§è®¸å¯çš„æŠ¥å‘Šï¼ˆæˆ–æ˜¾ç¤ºTUIæ¥å£ï¼‰ã€‚

item.title: ã€gopls can now suggest ways to modernize your Go codeã€‘GOPLç°åœ¨å¯ä»¥å»ºè®®æ‚¨ç°ä»£åŒ–GOä»£ç çš„æ–¹æ³•
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹543 â€” February 26, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Testing Concurrent Code with testing/synctest â€” Concurrency is one of Goâ€™s natural strengths, but testing heavily concurrent programs can be tricky. Go 1.24 introduces a new (though experimental and hidden behind an environment variable) package for testing code involving time or concurrency. The Go team wants you to have a play and send in yourÂ feedback.

Damien Neil

Prepare Your App for AI Agents â€” Stytch extends auth to handle permissions for AI agentsâ€”so your app can securely delegate access to agents or protect against agent-powered threats. Check out our GoÂ quickstart.

Stytch sponsor

Extensible Wasm Applications with Go â€” â€œâ€¦ the ability to build a WASI reactor and export Go functions to Wasm in Go 1.24 represent a significant step forward for Goâ€™s WebAssembly capabilities. These features empower developers to create more versatile and powerful Go-based Wasm applications â€¦â€

Cherry Mui

IN BRIEF:

  • Go's LSP server (gopls) has a new version out that adds a modernize analyzer that can suggest ways your Go code could be updated to take advantage of new language features and standard libraryÂ APIs.

  • Ben Boyter's Searchcode code search engine is a fantastic project and it's now powered entirely by Go and an epic 6 terabyte SQLite file.

  • Former core team member Brad Fitzpatrick ran into a memory leak with unique.Handle and has written up his findings.

  • ğŸ“º Go had its own track at the recent FOSDEM conference and you can enjoy videos of most of the talks here. Topics covered included eBPF, garbage collection, gRPC, and how Go 1.24's swiss maps implementation works. (I find the player on this site very flaky, but the 'Download' option works fine.)

  • ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º GopherCon Europe 2025 is.. a go! It takes place this June inÂ Berlin.

How to Manage Tool Dependencies in Go 1.24+ â€” Weâ€™ve touched on the new go tool subcommand a few times before, but this is a bit more usage-focused and includes a nice tip about separating your tools into their own moduleÂ file.

Alex Edwards

gno.land Offers Grants & Bounties for Building Go-Powered Decentralized Apps â€” App builders, Go enthusiasts, tinkerers: come and build on gno.land, a smart contract platform for a freer, fairerÂ world.

gno.land sponsor

ğŸ“„ Building RAG Systems in Go with Ent, Atlas, and pgvector Rotem Tamir (Ent)

ğŸ“„ Building a BitTorrent Client from the Ground Up in Go â€“ We linked this in 2020 but itâ€™s been doing the rounds on social media again and is fun toÂ revisit. Jesse Li

ğŸ“º From Strong to Weak: Weak Pointers in Go 1.24 Flo Woelki

ğŸ“„ Scaling gRPC with Kubernetes and Go Noam Yadgar

ğŸ“„ Practical OpenAPI in Go Alex Pliutau

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Minecraft From Scratch: A Simple Go Minecraft Clone â€” A fun project to replicate Minecraftâ€™s infinite, procedurally-generated navigable landscapes using Go and OpenGL 4.1 (as provided via the go-gl/gl bindings â€“ yes, cgo is requiredÂ here).

Gianluca Piccirillo

nativewebp: Native WebP Image Support for Go â€” WebP is a modern raster graphics format commonly used on the Web and this library lets you work with it (though only its VP8L lossless form, for now) from Go without dependencies.

Hugo Smits

WAX: JSX-Based Server-Side Rendering for Go â€” Generate server-side HTML with TSX/JSX templates inÂ Go.

Kita

godoc.nvim: Fuzzy Search Go's Docs from Neovim â€” Adds a quick way to search and browse Go documentation from within the Neovim editor.

Fredrik Averpil

GoChromecast: Discover Devices and Stream Media to Chromecast Devices â€” A Go-powered tool that implements the protocol used by ChromecastÂ devices.

A quick roundup of some of other interesting stories in the broader landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • Anthropic released Claude 3.7, a new version of its popular large language model, and reports and benchmarks so far show it's really good for coding.

  • An interesting look at how Git's core contributors configure their own gitÂ setups.

  • Browser developers collaborate via a project called Interop and focus on features to bring to the Web platform each year. Interop 2025's priorities include the Storage Access API, CSS improvements, WebAssembly enhancements, andÂ more.

  • The XOR operator, and logic gate, explained. (You can use bitwise XOR yourself in Go with the ^ operator.)
